head.title: Renewed Questions On Gulf War Attack

hedline.hl1: Renewed Questions On Gulf War Attack

block.p: One of the top American commanders in the Persian Gulf war came under investigation in 1991 after a member of his unit complained that his troops had pummeled retreating Iraqi forces in an unprovoked attack two days after a cease-fire went into effect.

Military investigators, who completed a secret report in 1991, had exonerated the commander, Barry McCaffrey, now a retired four-star Army general and President Clinton's top drug control official. And General McCaffrey says he is the victim of a journalist's attack.

One of the top American commanders in the Persian Gulf war came under investigation in 1991 after a member of his unit complained that his troops had pummeled retreating Iraqi forces in an unprovoked attack two days after a cease-fire went into effect.

Military investigators, who completed a secret report in 1991, had exonerated the commander, Barry McCaffrey, now a retired four-star Army general and President Clinton's top drug control official. And General McCaffrey says he is the victim of a journalist's attack.

But questions have been revived by a report in The New Yorker magazine that quotes senior Army officers, including an officer who fought alongside General McCaffrey, as saying the attack was unjustified.
